dt: {bc}permitted under football rules to catch a {d_link|forward pass|forward pass}

quotes.t: She wanted to start her own family. She was twenty-six and without prospects. At church her mother prayed, and at Crystal Nail, where she lacquered and lengthened, her mother asked customers about {qword}eligible{/qword} young men. She kept Li En's graduation photo mounted in the right corner of her mirror, so that every customer would see her daughter, diploma in hand.

… more than six years since the fall of the Taliban, fewer than 30% of {qword}eligible{/qword} girls are enrolled in schools, and the infrastructure is so poor that only a tiny fraction are likely to get the education they need to enjoy the fruits of emancipation.

et: Middle English, from Late Latin {it}eligibilis{/it}, from Latin {it}eligere{/it} to choose {ma}{mat|elect|}{/ma}
shortdef: qualified to participate or be chosen
permitted under football rules to catch a forward pass

dt: {bc}a person or thing that is qualified or permitted to do or be something {bc}one that is eligible for something

dt.t: As with the College of Cardinals and the papacy, where every cardinal, in theory, is eligible to be Pope but the number of real {wi}eligibles{/wi} is substantially smaller, so with the American Presidency.
… when she entered life, beautiful, accomplished, and an heiress, she had, of course, all the {wi}eligibles{/wi} … of the other sex sighing at her feet …

shortdef: a person or thing that is qualified or permitted to do or be something : one that is eligible for something

dt: {bc}an unmarried man who is regarded as a desirable husband

shortdef: an unmarried man who is regarded as a desirable husband

dt: {bc}{d_link|eligible|eligible:1} for something (such as a public office) again

dt.t: is {wi}reeligible{/wi} to serve on the council after a four-year hiatus

utxt.t: There is another strong feature in the new constitution, which I as strongly dislike. That is, the perpetual {wi}reeligibility{/wi} of the President.

shortdef: eligible for something (such as a public office) again
